question:
Which raga was composed by music emperor Mian Tansen to bring rain?

SSC MTS 2024
solution:
• Megh Malhar is the famous raga attributed to Mian Tansen, the musical genius in Emperor Akbar’s court.
  • It is believed that Raga Megh Malhar has the power to bring rain, and legends say Tansen could actually invoke rainfall by singing this raga.
  • It belongs to the Malhar group of ragas, traditionally sung during the monsoon season.
  • The raga combines Megh Raga and Malhar Raga, creating a soothing and majestic musical expression symbolizing clouds and rain.

Other Options:

  • Sharvari Tarang – No such raga is historically associated with rain.
  • Megh Pushpa – Sounds like a fictional or poetic name; not a known raga.
  • Mayurapriya – An uncommon raga, not associated with rainfall or Tansen.

question:
Who among the following is a Sarod player popularly known as ‘Sarod Samrat’?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_3: Ustad Amjad Ali Khan Bangash
solution:
• Ustad Amjad Ali Khan Bangash is a legendary Sarod player and is popularly known as ‘Sarod Samrat’ (Emperor of Sarod).
  • He belongs to the Senia Bangash Gharana, which traces its roots back to Miyan Tansen.
  • He made significant contributions in popularising the Sarod on global platforms.
  • Notable awards:
    • Padma Vibhushan (2001)
    • UNESCO Award, Sangeet Natak Akademi Award, and many international honors
  • He is also known for his compositions and teaching legacy, with sons Amaan and Ayaan Ali Bangash continuing the tradition.

Other Options – Short Info:

  • Pandit Shivkumar Sharma: Santoor maestro
  • Pandit Ravi Shankar: Sitar virtuoso
  • Pandit Kishan Maharaj: Renowned Tabla player

question:
The famous santoor player Pandit Shivkumar Sharma received the ________________________ in the year 1986.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_2: Sangeet Natak Akademi Award
solution:
• Pandit Shivkumar Sharma was a legendary Santoor maestro, who is credited for bringing this Kashmiri folk instrument into the realm of Indian classical music.
  • He received the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 1986 for his outstanding contribution to Hindustani classical music.
  • He was also honored with:
    • Padma Shri (1991)
    • Padma Bhushan (2001)
    • Padma Vibhushan (2022, posthumously)
  • He formed a famous duo with flautist Hariprasad Chaurasia, composing for films under the name Shiv-Hari.

Other Options – Short Info:

  • (a) Sanskriti Award – Given by Sanskriti Foundation for young talents.
  • (c) Kalidas Samman – Cultural award by Madhya Pradesh Government.
  • (d) Maharashtra Gurav Puraskar – State-level award by Maharashtra Govt.

question:
Harmonium player, Tulsidas Borkar, was awarded with the ___________ in 2016.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Tulsidas Borkar was a renowned Harmonium player known for elevating the harmonium to the status of a solo concert instrument in Indian classical music.
  • He was awarded the Padma Shri in 2016 by the Government of India for his contribution to the field of arts.
  • He trained under legends like Pandit Madhukar Pednekar and Pandit P. R. Atre.
  • Known for blending traditional harmonium playing with a more expressive, melodic style suitable for classical accompaniment and solo performances.

Other Options – Short Info:

  • (a) Bharat Ratna – India’s highest civilian award
  • (b) Padma Vibhushan – Second-highest civilian award in India
  • (d) Padma Bhushan – Third-highest civilian award in India

question:
Which famous santoor player was honoured with the Ustad Hafiz Ali Khan Award in 1998?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Pandit Shivkumar Sharma, the most celebrated Santoor player of India, was honoured with the Ustad Hafiz Ali Khan Award in 1998.
  • This award is given for excellence in classical music and is named after Ustad Hafiz Ali Khan, father of sarod maestro Amjad Ali Khan.
  • Pandit Sharma is credited with introducing Santoor to Hindustani classical music.
  • He was also a recipient of several prestigious awards including:
    • Padma Shri (1991)
    • Padma Bhushan (2001)
    • Padma Vibhushan (2022, posthumously)

Other Options – Short Info:

  • Abhay Sopori – Santoor player from Kashmir; son of Bhajan Sopori.
  • Tarun Bhattacharya – Sangeet Natak Akademi Awardee (2018); known for innovation in santoor playing.
  • Satish Vyas – Disciple of Shivkumar Sharma; noted for global performances.

question:
Ali Akbar Khan is known for playing the ________.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Ustad Ali Akbar Khan was a legendary Sarod maestro of the Maihar Gharana.
  • He was the son of Baba Allauddin Khan, and trained under him in classical music.
  • He played a key role in popularising Indian classical music globally, especially in the USA.
  • He established the Ali Akbar College of Music in California in 1967.
  • Major Awards:
    • Padma Vibhushan (1989)
    • Padma Bhushan (1975)
    • Sangeet Natak Akademi Award (1963)
    • First Indian musician to receive the MacArthur Fellowship (1991).

question:
In 2002, Zakir Hussain became the youngest percussionist to be honoured with which award?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_3: Sangeet Natak Akademi Award
solution:
• Ustad Zakir Hussain was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 2002, becoming the youngest percussionist to receive this honour at that time.
  • He is globally acclaimed for his mastery of the Tabla.
  • He is the son of Ustad Alla Rakha, another tabla maestro.
  • Zakir Hussain has collaborated with both Indian classical legends and international artists.
  • Major Awards:
    • Padma Shri (1988)
    • Padma Bhushan (2002)
    • Sangeet Natak Akademi Award (1990)
    • Grammy Awards (1992 & 2009) for world music collaborations
    • National Heritage Fellowship (1999) – USA's highest award in folk and traditional arts

question:
The Maharashtra Bhushan was conferred upon _________________ in the year 2002.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_4: Pandit Hari Prasad Chaurasia
solution:
• Pandit Bhimsen Joshi was honoured with the Maharashtra Bhushan in 2002.
  • He was a legendary Hindustani classical vocalist of the Kirana Gharana.
  • Known for his khayal renditions and powerful voice.
  • Major Awards:
    • Padma Shri (1972)
    • Padma Bhushan (1985)
    • Padma Vibhushan (1999)
    • Bharat Ratna (2008)

Other Options – Short Important Details:

  • Pandit Jasraj: Hindustani vocalist of Mewati Gharana, famous for devotional music; received Padma Vibhushan (2000)
  • Pandit Ravi Shankar: World-famous sitar player, promoted Indian music globally; awarded Bharat Ratna (1999)
  • Pandit Hariprasad Chaurasia: Renowned bansuri (flute) maestro; awarded Padma Vibhushan (2000)

question:
Pandit Omkar Nath Thakur was a student of ____________.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_1: Ustad Abdul Karim Khan
option_2: Pandit Vishnu Digambar Paluskar
option_3: Pandit Vishnu Narayan Bhatkhande
option_4: Pandit Gopal Shankar Mishra
solution:
• Pandit Omkarnath Thakur was a disciple of Pandit Vishnu Digambar Paluskar, the pioneer of the Gandharva Mahavidyalaya movement.
  • He was a noted Hindustani classical vocalist known for his patriotic and devotional renderings.
  • Contributed significantly to music education and was a respected musicologist.
  • Honoured with Padma Shri in 1955 for his contribution to Indian classical music.

Other Options – Short Important Details:

  • Ustad Abdul Karim Khan – Founder of the Kirana Gharana, known for melodious khayal singing.
  • Pandit Vishnu Narayan Bhatkhande – Renowned musicologist, developed Hindustani music notation system.
  • Pandit Gopal Shankar Mishra – Known for playing the Vichitra Veena; a distinguished instrumentalist.

question:
Who among the following was the youngest instrumentalist to be awarded the Padma Bhushan, the third highest civilian award of India in 2002?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Ustad Zakir Hussain was the youngest instrumentalist to receive the Padma Bhushan in 2002.
  • He is a globally renowned tabla virtuoso, known for blending Indian classical music with global percussion styles.
  • Recognized for elevating the tabla to a solo concert instrument on the international stage.
  • He has also received the Padma Shri (1988) and Padma Vibhushan (2023).

Other Options – Short Important Details:

  • Pandit Ravi Shankar – Sitar maestro, Bharat Ratna awardee (1999), known for globalizing Indian classical music.
  • Pandit Bhimsen Joshi – Hindustani classical vocalist of the Kirana Gharana, Bharat Ratna (2008).
  • Ustad Bismillah Khan – Shehnai legend, Bharat Ratna (2001), known for bringing shehnai to concert platforms.

question:
Sitar maestro, Pandit Ravi Shankar was awarded which of the following awards by the Government of India in 1999?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Pandit Ravi Shankar, the legendary sitar maestro, was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1999 by the Government of India.
  • He is regarded as one of the greatest proponents of Indian classical music worldwide.
  • Known for his global collaborations, especially with George Harrison of The Beatles.
  • He also received Padma Bhushan (1967) and Padma Vibhushan (1981) before the Bharat Ratna.
  • His contributions significantly helped popularize Indian classical music across the world.

question:
Which of the following awards was won by Lata Mangeshkar in the year 2001?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_2: Filmfare Lifetime Achievement Award
solution:
• Lata Mangeshkar, legendary playback singer, was awarded the Bharat Ratna in the year 2001.
  • She is one of the most iconic and respected voices in Indian music history.
  • She had previously received Padma Bhushan (1969), Padma Vibhushan (1999), and Dadasaheb Phalke Award (1989).
  • With a career spanning over seven decades, she recorded songs in over 36 languages.
  • She is regarded as the "Nightingale of India" for her melodious voice.

question:
Who among the following is/was a famous sitarist?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
option_2: UstadBismillah Khan
option_3: PanditBhimsen Joshi
solution:
• Ravi Shankar:
    • Renowned sitar maestro.
    • Honoured with Bharat Ratna (1999).
    • Global ambassador of Indian classical music.
    • Collaborated with international artists like George Harrison.
  • Zakir Hussain:
    • Legendary tabla virtuoso.
    • Awarded Padma Bhushan (2002), youngest percussionist to receive it.
    • Also a Grammy Award winner.
  • Ustad Bismillah Khan:
    • Famous shehnai player.
    • Honoured with Bharat Ratna (2001).
    • Known for bringing shehnai to the concert stage.
  • Pandit Bhimsen Joshi:
    • Celebrated Hindustani classical vocalist.
    • Honoured with Bharat Ratna (2008).
    • Known for his powerful voice and devotional music.

question:
Who among the following is the first vocalist to receive the Bharat Ratna in 2008 and is also credited to have popularised 'Khyal Gayaki'?

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Pandit Bhimsen Joshi:
    • First vocalist to receive the Bharat Ratna in 2008.
    • Revered exponent of Khyal Gayaki in Hindustani classical music.
    • Belonged to the Kirana Gharana.
    • Known for devotional bhajans and powerful voice modulation.
  • Begum Akhtar:
    • Known as Mallika-e-Ghazal.
    • Famous for Ghazals, Thumri, and Dadra.
    • Awarded Padma Shri, Padma Bhushan.
  • Gangubai Hangal:
    • Renowned Kirana Gharana vocalist.
    • Honoured with Padma Bhushan, Padma Vibhushan.
  • Vishnu Digambar Paluskar:
    • Great musicologist and reformer.
    • Founder of Gandharva Mahavidyalaya.
    • Key figure in revival of Indian classical music in early 20th century.

question:
Some of the talas invented by ____________ include Trimukhi, Panchamukhi, Saptamukhi and Navamukhi.

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• M. Balamuralikrishna:
    • A legendary Carnatic vocalist and composer.
    • Known for inventing new ragas and talas.
    • Talas invented include: Trimukhi, Panchamukhi, Saptamukhi, Navamukhi.
    • Awarded Padma Vibhushan, Sangeet Natak Akademi Award, and many others.
  • Yashraj:
    • No direct association with Indian classical music or tala creation.
    • Commonly associated with the film industry (Yash Raj Films).
  • Hariprasad Chaurasia:
    • Renowned bansuri (flute) maestro in Hindustani classical music.
    • Famous for his collaboration with Shivkumar Sharma in Shiv-Hari duo.
  • Bhimsen Joshi:
    • Hindustani classical vocalist, exponent of Kirana Gharana.
    • Known for his Khyal gayaki, bhajans, and powerful vocal range.

question:
The registered office of the Sangeet Natak Akademi is at:

SSC CGL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Sangeet Natak Akademi was established in 1952 by the Government of India.
  • Its registered office is located in New Delhi, at Rabindra Bhavan, Feroze Shah Road.
  • It functions under the Ministry of Culture as an autonomous body.
  • It promotes and preserves India's performing arts: music, dance, and drama.
  • It has recognised 8 classical dance forms, including:
    1. Bharatanatyam
    2. Kathak
    3. Kathakali
    4. Kuchipudi
    5. Manipuri
    6. Mohiniyattam
    7. Odissi
    8. Sattriya (Recognised in 2000)
  • Additionally, Chhau dance is recognised as a semi-classical dance form.
    • It combines elements of martial arts, tribal and folk traditions.
    • Three styles: Purulia (WB), Mayurbhanj (Odisha), Seraikella (Jharkhand).

question:
Dakshinamurthy Pillai was an Indian musician who used to play __________.

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Dakshinamurthy Pillai was a legendary Indian percussionist in the Carnatic music tradition.
  • He was a master of the mridangam and also proficient in the kanjira, both key rhythm instruments in South Indian classical music.
  • Born in 1875 in Trichy, he trained under Pudukottai Manpundia Pillai and became a central figure in the Pudukottai percussion tradition.
  • He accompanied many great Carnatic vocalists and was revered for his tala precision and expressive accompaniment.
  • His disciples include stalwarts like Palani Subramania Pillai and Palghat Mani Iyer, who carried forward his rhythmic legacy.

question:
Emani Sankara Sastry was one of the first Carnatic maestros to use a contact microphone to harness the full potential of which musical instrument?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Emani Sankara Sastry was a legendary Carnatic veena maestro, born in 1922 in Draksharamam, Andhra Pradesh.
  • He was among the first Carnatic instrumentalists to use a contact microphone to amplify the tonal richness of the veena, enhancing its presence in concert settings2.
  • His innovative use of technology helped elevate the veena’s status as a solo concert instrument in modern times.
  • Emani was also known for his orchestral compositions and collaborations with Hindustani musicians like Pandit Ravi Shankar and Ustad Abdul Halim Jaffer Khan
  • He served as the Chief Producer of Music at All India Radio and was instrumental in shaping national orchestral presentations.

question:
Rattan Mohan Sharma is associated with which of the following musical gharanas?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Rattan Mohan Sharma is a renowned Indian classical vocalist associated with the Mewati Gharana.
  • He is the nephew and disciple of Pandit Jasraj, one of the most celebrated exponents of the Mewati tradition.
  • His repertoire includes khayal, tarana, Haveli Sangeet, bhajans, and Rajasthani folk music.
  • He is known for his powerful voice, mastery over taans, and devotional renditions.
  • Sharma has received several honors including the Mewati Gharana Gaurav Puraskar and Sur Ratna titles.

question:
Anil Srinivasan is one of the unique artists of India who plays which musical instrument?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Anil Srinivasan is a renowned Indian classical pianist known for fusing Western classical piano with Indian Carnatic music.
  • He has collaborated with numerous classical vocalists to create a distinct musical style that bridges two rich traditions.
  • His innovative approach has gained international recognition, making the piano his signature instrument.

question:
Which of the following musical instruments was played by Ustad Asad Ali Khan?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Ustad Asad Ali Khan was a celebrated master of the Rudra Veena, an ancient Indian string instrument known for its deep, meditative tones.
  • He was one of the last active performers of this rare instrument and represented the Khandarbani Gharana of Dhrupad music.
  • His efforts to preserve and popularize Rudra Veena earned him national recognition.
  • In 2008, he was honored with the Padma Bhushan, India’s third-highest civilian award, for his contributions to classical music.

question:
Which of the following Gharanas of Kathak was Pandit Ishwari Prasad related to?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Pandit Ishwari Prasad is considered the founding figure of the Lucknow Gharana of Kathak.
  • He was a court dancer in the Nawab of Awadh's durbar during the 18th century and is credited with systematizing the style.
  • This Gharana emphasizes graceful movements, intricate expressions (abhinaya), and delicate footwork.
  • The Lucknow style integrates bhava (emotion) and nazakat (elegance), making it distinct from the rhythmic vigor of the Jaipur Gharana.

question:
Shruti Sadolikar is an Indian classical singer of the Khayal genre of which Gharana?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Shruti Sadolikar is a distinguished Indian classical vocalist known for her mastery in the Khayal genre.
  • She belongs to the Jaipur-Atrauli Gharana, a school of music founded by Alladiya Khan.
  • This Gharana is renowned for its emphasis on complex and rare ragas, intricate compositions, and systematic raga development.
  • Shruti Sadolikar trained under her father, Pandit Wamanrao Sadolikar, and Ustad Gulubhai Jasdanwalla—both stalwarts of the same tradition.

question:
She was a Carnatic legendary singer who sang in Europe, North America and at the United Nations General Assembly. Who was she?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Madurai Shanmukhavadivu Subbulakshmi, known as M. S. Subbulakshmi, was a legendary Carnatic vocalist whose music transcended national and cultural boundaries.
  • In 1966, she became the first Indian musician to perform at the United Nations General Assembly.
  • She was also the first Indian woman to be awarded the Bharat Ratna—India's highest civilian honor—in the year 1998.
  • Her contributions to Indian classical music earned her immense global respect, and she remains a timeless icon, often referred to as the Queen of Music.

question:
‘Streets Of Calcutta’ and ‘Dancing Drums’ are the two popular tracks of ______________.

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Ananda Shankar was a revolutionary Indian musician celebrated for fusing Indian classical music with Western rock and electronic styles.
  • His famous instrumental tracks like "Streets of Calcutta" and "Dancing Drums" showcase this fusion, blending sitar with modern rhythms.
  • He was the son of Uday Shankar (renowned dancer) and nephew of sitar legend Ravi Shankar.
  • These tracks made a significant mark in the 1970s and are still cherished in world music circles.

Other Options — Instrument Associations:

  • Anoushka Shankar – Sitar
  • Zakir Hussain – Tabla
  • Begum Akhtar – Vocals (Ghazal, Thumri)

question:
Raga 'Laswanti' was composed by whom among the following personalities?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
option_4: Ustad Ali Akbar Khan
solution:
• Ustad Ali Akbar Khan, the legendary sarod maestro, is credited with composing the raga Laswanti.
  • He was renowned for his creativity and mastery in both performing and composing new ragas within the Hindustani classical tradition.
  • Raga Laswanti is a relatively modern creation and reflects his deep understanding of melody, expression, and structure.
  • Ustad Ali Akbar Khan was a key figure of the Maihar Gharana and was instrumental in introducing Indian classical music to the West.

question:
Which title was given to Begum Akhtar?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Begum Akhtar was lovingly known as the "Queen of Ghazals" for her timeless and expressive contribution to the ghazal genre in Indian music.
  • Her rich, emotive voice brought grace to ghazals, along with thumri and dadra compositions.
  • She was awarded the Padma Shri in 1968 and the Padma Bhushan in 1975 for her contributions to Indian classical music.
  • Girija Devi is known as “Queen of Thumris”.

question:
Who among the following was a Shehnai player and performed at Delhi’s Red Fort as the Indian flag unfurled at the hour of India’s independence on 15 August 1947?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Ustad Bismillah Khan, a legendary Shehnai maestro, had the historic honor of performing at the Red Fort in Delhi on 15 August 1947, marking the moment India gained independence.
  • His soulful rendition of the Shehnai immediately after Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru's iconic "Tryst with Destiny" speech became symbolic of India’s cultural pride and freedom.
  • Ustad Bismillah Khan played a crucial role in elevating the shehnai from a wedding and temple instrument to a stage-worthy classical instrument.
  • He was later awarded prestigious honors including the Bharat Ratna in 2001, the highest civilian award in India.

question:
Who among the following singers is the recipient of all the three awards Padma Shri, Padma Bhushan and Padma Vibhushan?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• S. P. Balasubrahmanyam, one of India’s most versatile and celebrated playback singers, is the only artist among the given options to have received all three prestigious civilian awards:
    • Padma Shri in 2001
    • Padma Bhushan in 2011
    • Padma Vibhushan (posthumously) in 2021
  • His career spanned multiple languages and over 40,000 recorded songs, making him a legendary figure in Indian music history.

question:
Which dance and singing form of Manipur was inscribed on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2013?

SSC GD 2025 T-1
solution:
• Sankirtana is a ritual singing, drumming, and dancing art form of Manipur, deeply rooted in the Vaishnavite tradition.
  • It involves male performers who sing and play drums (mridanga) and cymbals (kartal) while dancing rhythmically in temple courtyards or sacred spaces.
  • The performances are not only devotional but also mark important life-cycle events and festivals.
  • Recognizing its cultural and spiritual significance, UNESCO inscribed Sankirtana on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2013.

question:
The famous book ‘Sangraha Choodamani’, which deals with the current system of Carnatic music was written by:

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• ‘Sangraha Choodamani’ is a significant musicological text related to Carnatic music.
  • It was written by Govindacharya.
  • The book provides a systematic framework for raga classification in Carnatic music.
  • It introduced the Melakarta raga system, which forms the basis of present-day Carnatic raga organization.

Other options:

  • Haripala: Known for his contributions to ancient Indian music theory, but not related to Sangraha Choodamani.
  • Matanga: Author of Brihaddeshi, the earliest known text that mentions ‘raga’.
  • Damodara Misra: A scholar of Hindustani music, not associated with Carnatic system formation.

question:
Which of the following folk music of Chhattisgarh is based on the epic Mahabharata?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Pandavani is a folk music and narrative performance style from Chhattisgarh.
  • It is based on the epic Mahabharata, especially focusing on Bhima as the central character.
  • The performance includes music, singing, storytelling, and dramatic narration.
  • Teejan Bai is one of the most renowned exponents of Pandavani.

Other options:

  • Paani Haari: Rajasthani folk music sung by women while fetching water.
  • Ghumar: Traditional dance and music form of Rajasthan.
  • Maand: Classical style of folk singing from Rajasthan, not linked to Mahabharata.

question:
Chhannulal Mishra is related to which Musical Lineage?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Chhannulal Mishra is a renowned Hindustani classical vocalist.
  • He belongs to the Kirana Gharana, known for its emphasis on melodic development and swara purity.
  • He is also famous for his thumri, khayal, and bhajan performances.
  • The Kirana Gharana has produced legendary artists like Abdul Karim Khan and Bhimsen Joshi.

Other options:

  • Jaipur Gharana – Known for its intricate rhythmic patterns, especially in khayal singing.
  • Agra Gharana – Blends dhrupad and khayal, known for powerful voice projection.
  • Delhi Gharana – Prominent in tabla tradition more than vocal.

question:
Which of the following types is NOT an element of classical Carnatic music?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Thumri is NOT an element of classical Carnatic music.
  • It is a semi-classical vocal form in Hindustani music, known for romantic and devotional expressions.
  • Kriti, Padam, and Sthayi are important parts of Carnatic music:
    • Kriti – A major compositional form, usually devotional.
    • Padam – A slow lyrical composition, used in classical dance.
    • Sthayi – Refers to a melodic register or range of notes used in raga elaboration.

question:
Bharat Muni, in his Natya Shastra, categorises musical instruments into four different parts. What is the categorisation of musical instruments by Bharat Muni based on?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
option_1: Different sounds of the musical instruments
option_2: The shape of the musical instruments
option_3: The uses of the musical instruments in different occasions, such as wedding, festivals and public gathering
option_4: Different materials used in the musical instruments
solution:
• Bharat Muni authored the Natya Shastra, an ancient Sanskrit treatise on performing arts.
  • In it, he classified musical instruments into four categories:
    • Tat (stringed),
    • Sushir (wind),
    • Avanaddh (percussion),
    • Ghana (solid).
  • The basis of this classification is the different sounds produced by these instruments.
  • It does not depend on shape, material, or occasion of use.

question:
In classical Carnatic music, tempo is called as ________.

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• In classical Carnatic music, the term tempo or speed of a musical composition is referred to as “Laya.”
  • Laya determines the rhythmic timing of a performance, essential for maintaining uniformity and discipline in the rendition.
  • It has three main types:
    • Vilambita Laya (slow)
    • Madhyama Laya (medium)
    • Druta Laya (fast)

question:
In Hindustani classical music, according to Vishnu Narayana Bhatkhande, how many thaats are the origins of ragas?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• In Hindustani classical music, Vishnu Narayana Bhatkhande was a key musicologist who introduced a systematic classification of ragas.
  • He classified ragas under 10 parent scales, which are called "Thaats."
  • These 10 Thaats are: Bilawal, Kafi, Khamaj, Bhairav, Bhairavi, Asavari, Todi, Marwa, Purvi, and Kalyan.
  • This system helped in standardizing the structure and study of ragas in North Indian music.

question:
Who among the following is a singer of Hindustani classical music?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Shubha Mudgal is a renowned Hindustani classical music singer.
  • She is known for her versatility in genres like khayal, thumri, dadra, and even Indian pop music.
  • She has received several awards including the Padma Shri for her contribution to Indian music.

Other Options:

  • Aruna Sairam – Famous Carnatic vocalist.
  • S Sowmya – Renowned Carnatic music singer.
  • Sudha Ragunathan – Prominent Carnatic classical vocalist.

question:
Ohira folk music is primarily associated with one of the popular festivals of which of the following states?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Ohira is a type of folk music primarily associated with tribal communities of Jharkhand.
  • It is commonly sung during local festivals and traditional events, especially in tribal gatherings.
  • The songs convey folk tales, customs, and collective emotions of the community.

Other Options:

  • Kerala – Known for folk forms like Oppana, Theyyam, and Margamkali.
  • Assam – Known for Bihu music and dance, tied to agricultural festivals.
  • Karnataka – Popular for Dollu Kunitha, Yakshagana, and Lavani folk traditions.

question:
The music of traditional _______ consists of thumri and other lyrical song forms.

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• The music of traditional Kathak consists of thumri, dadra, and other lyrical and romantic song forms.
  • Thumri is known for its expressive, devotional, and romantic content, often depicting themes from Radha-Krishna love stories.
  • Kathak dancers use these lyrical forms to portray abhinaya (expressions) effectively.
  • The music includes tabla, sarangi, and harmonium as accompaniment.

Other Options:

  • Kuchipudi – Uses Carnatic music; songs are mostly in Telugu.
  • Sattriya – Uses devotional songs (Borgeet) from Vaishnavism, mainly in Assamese.
  • Kathakali – Accompanied by percussive instruments like chenda and vocal forms in Manipravalam (a blend of Malayalam and Sanskrit).

question:
Which folk music is a mix of Indian and western music and is popular in Goa?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Mando is a Goan folk music form that represents a blend of Indian and Western musical elements.
  • It originated among the Catholic elite in Goa during the Portuguese colonial period.
  • Features Portuguese-style guitars and violins combined with Indian rhythms and melodies.
  • Typically sung in the Konkani language with themes of love, tragedy, and social issues.

Other Options:

  • Maand – A folk music style from Rajasthan, expressing heroism and romance.
  • Pawada – A form of ballad music in Maharashtra, mainly praises heroes and saints.
  • Pai songs – Sung in Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh, especially during rain festivals, often accompanied by Saria dance.

question:
In which year was the Marris College of Music established in India?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Marris College of Music was established in the year 1926.
  • Located in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, it was founded by Vishnu Narayan Bhatkhande, a pioneer in Indian classical musicology.
  • The institution aimed at providing systematic education in Hindustani classical music.
  • Today, it is known as the Bhatkhande Music Institute (Deemed University).

question:
________ is a musical composition that expresses devotion through madhura bhakti.

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• Padam is a musical composition used in Carnatic classical music.
  • It expresses devotion through madhura bhakti (sweet/devotional love, often towards a deity like Krishna).
  • Typically performed in Bharatanatyam and Mohiniyattam dance forms.
  • The lyrics are slow-paced, emotional, and convey intense devotion or romantic yearning for the divine.

Other Options (Extra Info):

  • Tillana – A rhythmic piece usually performed at the end of a concert or dance recital; focused on pure dance (nritta) and rhythm.
  • Kriti – The most common type of Carnatic composition; structured and focused on bhakti (devotion) but not always madhura bhakti.
  • Gita – A simple musical composition, usually taught to beginners; introduces basic raga and tala concepts.

question:
Which of the following is NOT related to the ‘Trinity of Carnatic Music’?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
solution:
• The Trinity of Carnatic Music refers to three iconic composers who significantly shaped the structure and depth of Carnatic classical music.
  • The members of this trinity are:
    • Tyagaraja
    • Syama Shastri
    • Muthuswami Dikshitar
  • These three composers lived during the 18th–19th centuries and composed thousands of kritis.
  • Purandara Dasa, although a pioneer of Carnatic music, lived earlier (15th–16th century) and is known as the "Father of Carnatic Music", but not part of the Trinity.

question:
Which statement about Classical Carnatic Music is correct?

SSC CHSL 2024 T-1
option_1: The compositions are either in Malayalam, Marathi, Tamil or Bengali.
option_2: The compositions are either in Marathi, Odia, Konkani or Bengali.
option_3: The compositions are either in Telugu, Malayalam, Hindi or Sanskrit.
option_4: The compositions are either in Telugu, Kannada, Tamil or Sanskrit.
solution:
• Carnatic music compositions are traditionally written in South Indian languages.
  • The most commonly used languages in Carnatic compositions are:
    • Telugu – used by Tyagaraja
    • Kannada – used by Purandara Dasa
    • Tamil – used by Arunachala Kavi, Papanasam Sivan
    • Sanskrit – used in many devotional hymns
  • These languages reflect the geographical and cultural origins of Carnatic music, which is rooted in South India.

question:
‘Raga Mala’ is an autobiography of who among the following musicians?

SSC STENO 2024 T-1
solution:
• ‘Raga Mala’ is the autobiography of Pandit Ravi Shankar, one of India’s most renowned sitar players.
  • The book was edited by George Harrison, the lead guitarist of The Beatles, who had a close association with Ravi Shankar.
  • It gives insights into Ravi Shankar’s personal life, musical journey, and global contributions to Indian classical music.
  • He played a pivotal role in popularizing Indian classical music in the West.

question:
Who among the following musicians plays Carnatic music and also known as ‘God of Ghatam’?

SSC STENO 2024 T-1
solution:
• T.H. Vinayakram is a renowned Carnatic percussionist known for playing the Ghatam, a traditional Indian clay pot instrument.
  • He is popularly known as the ‘God of Ghatam’ due to his unmatched expertise and contributions.
  • He has performed globally with both Indian classical and fusion music artists.
  • He was the first South Indian percussionist to perform at the Grammy Awards.

question:
Chitti Babu is a well-known ________.

SSC STENO 2024 T-1
solution:
• Chitti Babu was a renowned Veena player from South India.
  • He played a major role in popularising the Carnatic veena at the international level.
  • His style was known for melodic clarity, technical brilliance, and emotional depth.
  • He was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 1990 for his contribution to instrumental music.

Other options – Famous musicians:

  • Sarod player – Ustad Amjad Ali Khan
  • Sitar player – Pandit Ravi Shankar
  • Tabla player – Ustad Zakir Hussain

question:
Who among the following Assamese playback singers was conferred with Bharat Ratna in 2019?

SSC STENO 2024 T-1
solution:
• Bhupen Hazarika was a legendary Assamese playback singer, composer, lyricist, poet, and filmmaker.
  • He is best remembered for his deep baritone voice and songs that touched on humanity, communal amity, and universal brotherhood.
  • He was conferred Bharat Ratna (posthumously) in 2019, India's highest civilian honour.
  • Bhupen Hazarika’s songs remain iconic across Assam and the northeastern region.

Other Options – Information on Singers:

  • Zoi Barua – Emerging Assamese singer, not widely known nationally.
  • Zubeen Garg – Popular Assamese and Bollywood playback singer known for the song "Ya Ali".
  • Jayanta Hazarika – Brother of Bhupen Hazarika, known for modern Assamese music compositions.

question:
Dr. Jayanthi Kumaresh is famous for playing the ________.

SSC STENO 2024 T-1
solution:
• Dr. Jayanthi Kumaresh is a renowned Saraswati Veena player and one of the most prominent female veena artists in the world.
  • She represents six generations of veena playing tradition in her family.
  • Known for her deep understanding of Carnatic classical music, she has performed globally.
  • She was conferred the Kalaimamani Award by the Government of Tamil Nadu and Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 2023.

Other Options – Famous Artists:

  • Ghatam – T.H. Vinayakram, known as the "God of Ghatam".
  • Mridangam – Palghat Mani Iyer, a legendary mridangam maestro.
  • Harmonium – Pandit Tulsidas Borkar, known for his solo harmonium performances.
